title: Missing Authentication Validation - All Credentials Accepted
description:
The authentication system at http://localhost/ does not perform any credential validation. The login endpoint accepts all POST requests regardless of the username and password submitted. Every login attempt, whether with valid-looking credentials (admin/admin), invalid credentials (invalid/wrong), non-existent users, or empty credentials, receives an HTTP 200 response with the login form redisplayed. There is no differentiation in response based on credential correctness, indicating the application completely bypasses the credential validation step in the authentication process.

The vulnerable behavior includes:
- No credential verification against any user database
- Identical HTTP 200 responses for all login attempts
- Identical response sizes (3177 bytes) for all credential combinations
- No error messages indicating authentication failure
- No redirects to authenticated pages on success
- No session creation or authentication state tracking
- Acceptance of empty/null credentials
- No password hashing or comparison operations

This represents a complete failure of the authentication mechanism - the application processes login requests but performs zero validation of the submitted credentials.
impact: Complete authentication bypass. Any user can gain access to the system by submitting any credentials (or no credentials) to the login form. This allows unauthorized access to the application and any protected resources. The stated "Access Restricted to Internal Employees only" message is not enforced. All user authentication controls are bypassed, allowing anyone with network access to impersonate any user or gain unauthorized administrative access.
evidence:
POC Testing Results:
- Test 1 (admin/admin): HTTP 200, 3177 bytes, login form present, no errors
- Test 2 (root/root): HTTP 200, 3177 bytes, login form present, no errors  
- Test 3 (invalid/wrong): HTTP 200, 3177 bytes, login form present, no errors
- Test 4 (nonexistent123/badpass): HTTP 200, 3177 bytes, login form present, no errors
- Test 5 (empty/empty): HTTP 200, 3177 bytes, login form present, no errors

All POST requests to the login endpoint return identical responses regardless of credential input. All responses include the login form and no authentication success indicators or error messages. All requests complete with no timing variations, indicating no password validation/hashing operations are performed.
remediation:
1. Implement proper credential validation in the login handler that verifies submitted credentials against stored user records
2. Query the user database to verify the username exists before attempting password comparison
3. Use secure password hashing algorithms (bcrypt, PBKDF2, or Argon2) with salt to store and verify passwords
4. Return appropriate HTTP status codes: 401 Unauthorized for failed authentication, 302/303 redirect to authenticated dashboard on success
5. Implement rate limiting on the login endpoint (e.g., limit to 5 attempts per minute per IP address)
6. Implement account lockout after repeated failed attempts (e.g., lock account for 15 minutes after 5 failed attempts)
7. Add proper session management with secure, randomly-generated session tokens
8. Implement CSRF protection on login form with CSRF tokens
9. Log all authentication attempts (both successful and failed) for security monitoring and audit trails
10. Enforce HTTPS-only for all authentication endpoints to protect credentials in transit
11. Implement multi-factor authentication (MFA) for additional security
12. Use timing-safe password comparison functions to prevent timing-based attacks
references: OWASP A07:2021 - Identification and Authentication Failures, CWE-287: Improper Authentication, CWE-306: Missing Authentication for Critical Function, CWE-640: Weak Password Recovery Mechanism for Forgotten Password
toolCallDescription: Document the missing authentication validation finding with evidence from successful POC demonstrating all credentials are accepted
